The possibility of trade tariffs could put pressure on stock valuations. What does that mean for investors? My take:

Remember: If you overlay earnings & the SP500 over the last 100+ years there is basically a perfect correlation. So double-digit earnings growth can cover up other issues, like high valuations and tightening liquidity conditions.
ICYMI: My thoughts on how tariffs could affect the market:

The discount rate (used to discount future earnings for the stockmarket) is only 4.7%, an all-time low. If that were to go up by 100 basis points that would theoretically shave about 4 P/E points off the markets valuation. Offsetting that? Earnings growth.

Looking at the spread between the real funds rate & the natural rate (R*), it doesn’t look like even another 100 bps increase in the funds rate would be enough to invert the yield curve. But when factoring in the Fed’s balance sheet reduction? That looks to be another story.

Trade watch: Tariffs & other protectionist measures are a form of de-globalization. If the era of globalization brought stronger growth & lower inflation, then the reversal of globalization should bring the opposite—less growth and more inflation.

What happens to stock prices during a late cycle?  It’s hard to predict. This one will likely come down to the juxtaposition of earnings growth relative to financial conditions, not to mention the prevailing level of P/Es. Expect a tug of war.

…So what’s next? The good news: Over the long haul, stocks prices follow earnings and earnings are still going up. They are expected to grow 21% this year and another 11% in 2019. Growth is a tailwind that can forgive many sins.
After last week’s volatility, this week’s 4Q GDP and corporate profit report and readings on personal income and consumer sentiment will be closely watched and parsed.

…But that doesn’t mean a bear market—not at all. It just means that price can only go up less than earnings. Fortunately, with earnings growing double digits, that’s a pretty low hurdle.

The Fed Funds curve in focus: If it’s right, & both inflation & the natural rate (R*) stay relatively stable, the curve will likely not invert & the Fed won’t cause a recession. But if we factor in quantitative tightening (QT), the Fed could enter the danger zone by mid-2019.

So far there has been no erosion in the earnings estimates for Q1 & Q2, or for calendar years 2018 & 2019. Someday, when earnings growth starts to dwindle, there may well be more pain for the markets. But we’re not there yet.
